Award.AwardTitle: Applied Engineering Technology - Many Pathways To Success

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is responding to the need for the college to develop responsive programs and innovative strategies that keep pace with fast-growing trends in technology and dramatic technological advances in industry. The introduction of an AAS degree in applied engineering technology at the college is designed to develop outreach strategies that leverage community partnership programs with industries and educational establishments in the surrounding region. Occupational majors in engineering technology allow students to take a variety of technical courses leading to a versatile degree which can be used directly for employment as a skilled technician or for transfer to a four-year institution. In addition to industry partnerships with Lockheed Martin and other firms and an educational partnership with Drexel University, the college plans to incorporate many companies, four-year institutions, high schools, and other community establishments into the program, uniting industries and educational institutions.

The intellectual merit of this project is manifested through the introduction of an AAS degree in applied engineering technology at the college, which stimulates and increases the level of learning by offering students educational opportunities which far exceed current curriculum options. By ultimately providing concentrations in a variety of technical areas, students can choose a path that is compatible with their academic interests and career choices. This degree encourages the study of engineering technology by providing a career pathway for students from the community college to either a technological position in industry or into a four-year program. Both employment and transfer allow for advancement of the student leading to an expanded and varied educational experience. In addition students have the opportunity to increase their educational level in the same field as their degrees. The versatility of the major allows students the opportunity to explore other career options through co-ops, internships, and job opportunities. This allows for further advancement of students, which in turn provides transfer institutions and industries with a broader, more in-depth intellectual base, ultimately leading to a better educated, more highly skilled workforce.

The broader impacts include the development of the AAS degree in applied engineering technology, which leads to a diverse population of students entering the program at many different stages in their educational careers. High schools, the community college, four-year institutions and industries are connected through educational opportunities, co-ops, internships, and job opportunities. Students who do not want the mathematical rigor of a conventional engineering track have the option of studying engineering technology from an algebra-based hands-on approach. Thus, the AAS degree in applied engineering technology is available to a much wider array of students with more diverse backgrounds than the AA degree in engineering. The goal is to actively recruit women and underrepresented minority students as well as students with disabilities. Partnerships include research opportunities for faculty members.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funds from our NSF grant, Applied Engineering Technology: Many Pathways to Success, Award ID: 1103891, allowed Bucks County Community College (Bucks) to improve the curriculum of the current Associate of Arts (AA) degree in engineering assuring a more seamless transfer to four-year schools and for the establishment of an Applied Associate of Science (AAS) degree in Applied Engineering Technology. Our newly established engineering technology program is designed to educate and train students in the theory, laboratory components and skills necessary to enter directly into the work force as a skilled technician. Bucks has been able to develop curricula and modernize laboratories through this grant.

       The broader impacts of this grant have included student and faculty involvement in numerous synergistic activities to promote the engineering technology major including outreach to local high schools, web presence, and promotional initiatives at the College and in the community. These initiatives included the founding of an engineering club which is involved in projects such as quadrotor research, building their own 3D printer, and community service in the area of 3D printing. Funds from this grant allowed us to purchase a 3D printer which has enabled students to expand their research efforts. Community outreach involves local high schools, conferences, workshops for middle school girls, and the cub scouts. Faculty initiatives have included open houses, workshops, tours, visits to local high schools, and STEM demonstrations. Bucks has also been in the process of completing and updating articulation agreements with a number of local educational establishments, including both high schools and universities. Efforts to extend articulation to schools around the region are underway and will continue beyond the scope of this grant. Bucks has extended the engineering technology major farther into the community by completing an outside review of our own Advanced Manufacturing Training Center (AMTC), which is part of the Bucks Center for Workforce Development, for possible pathways into our engineering technology program. Reviewers (Advisory Board members from Drexel, Temple and The College of New Jersey) were impressed with both our credit and non-credit programs. These reviewers, in collaboration with Bucks faculty, developed a plan to streamline transition of graduates of the AMTC courses into our engineering technology program. The plan has provided additional pathways for students seeking the engineering technology degree.

The intellectual merit of this effort has been manifested through the modernization of laboratories and enhancement of curricula, and in the involvement of students in real-world collaborative research opportunities in the areas of quadrotor technology and 3D printing. Bucks students in collaboration with local high school students were fortunate to be involved in an innovative, collaborative research project into quadrotor technology. Different from a helicopter which has one propeller, a quadrotor is a four-propeller unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) practical for applications in a wide variety of vital areas such as search and rescue, first response, surveillance and environmental monitoring which have positive societal impacts. These opportunities have been supported through our ATE grant, as well as the Bucks Foundation, Dow Chemical’s DowGives program, and faculty and students of Montgomery County Community College (MCCC). Collaboration between engineering, engineering technology, and computer science has also provided a real-world experience for our students. Bucks students collaborated with high schools, higher education institutions, and industry to investigate aspects of the quadrotor commonly analyzed at universities, including vehicle sta...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Funds from our NSF grant, Applied Engineering Technology: Many Pathways to Success, Award ID: 1103891, allowed Bucks County Community College (Bucks) to improve the curriculum of the current Associate of Arts (AA) degree in engineering assuring a more seamless transfer to four-year schools and for the establishment of an Applied Associate of Science (AAS) degree in Applied Engineering Technology. Our newly established engineering technology program is designed to educate and train students in the theory, laboratory components and skills necessary to enter directly into the work force as a skilled technician. Bucks has been able to develop curricula and modernize laboratories through this grant. The broader impacts of this grant have included student and faculty involvement in numerous synergistic activities to promote the engineering technology major including outreach to local high schools, web presence, and promotional initiatives at the College and in the community. These initiatives included the founding of an engineering club which is involved in projects such as quadrotor research, building their own 3D printer, and community service in the area of 3D printing. Funds from this grant allowed us to purchase a 3D printer which has enabled students to expand their research efforts. Community outreach involves local high schools, conferences, workshops for middle school girls, and the cub scouts. Faculty initiatives have included open houses, workshops, tours, visits to local high schools, and STEM demonstrations. Bucks has also been in the process of completing and updating articulation agreements with a number of local educational establishments, including both high schools and universities. Efforts to extend articulation to schools around the region are underway and will continue beyond the scope of this grant. Bucks has extended the engineering technology major farther into the community by completing an outside review of our own Advanced Manufacturing Training Center (AMTC), which is part of the Bucks Center for Workforce Development, for possible pathways into our engineering technology program. Reviewers (Advisory Board members from Drexel, Temple and The College of New Jersey) were impressed with both our credit and non-credit programs. These reviewers, in collaboration with Bucks faculty, developed a plan to streamline transition of graduates of the AMTC courses into our engineering technology program. The plan has provided additional pathways for students seeking the engineering technology degree. The intellectual merit of this effort has been manifested through the modernization of laboratories and enhancement of curricula, and in the involvement of students in real-world collaborative research opportunities in the areas of quadrotor technology and 3D printing. Bucks students in collaboration with local high school students were fortunate to be involved in an innovative, collaborative research project into quadrotor technology. Different from a helicopter which has one propeller, a quadrotor is a four-propeller unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) practical for applications in a wide variety of vital areas such as search and rescue, first response, surveillance and environmental monitoring which have positive societal impacts. These opportunities have been supported through our ATE grant, as well as the Bucks Foundation, Dow ChemicalÆs DowGives program, and faculty and students of Montgomery County Community College (MCCC). Collaboration between engineering, engineering technology, and computer science has also provided a real-world experience for our students. Bucks students collaborated with high schools, higher education institutions, and industry to investigate aspects of the quadrotor commonly analyzed at universities, including vehicle stability, power limitations, long range communications, fail-safes, and environmental applications.
